awd_titl_txt: Conference: Contagion on Complex Social Systems 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
Studying how information, diseases, and ideas spread through society is crucial for understanding and addressing pressing societal issues, including public health crises, misinformation, and national security. Our current understanding of these processes is fragmented because research on contagion processes occurs in silos. This award provides funding for the second edition of the "Contagion on Complex Social Systems" (CCSS)  conference, which serves as a platform for researchers from diverse fields to exchange ideas and develop innovative approaches for modeling contagion in complex social systems. There will be six invited talks from leading researchers in their respective fields, the opportunity for up to 25 contributed talks, and expert-led discussions. An essential focus of the conference is training the scientific workforce in cutting-edge methods and tools, thus fostering the growth of a skilled research community.

The CCSS conference aims to promote interdisciplinary collaboration and advance the understanding of contagion processes in social systems by bringing together researchers from applied mathematics, social sciences, public health, epidemiology, economics, ecology, and computer science. The conference features presentations on topics such as epidemic modeling, misinformation spread, and financial contagion, with the explicit aim of attaining an integrated understanding of contagion processes. The conference will emphasize support to early career researchers and is committed to fostering diversity and inclusion by encouraging participation from underrepresented groups. Videos of the lectures and transcript will be uploaded on the conference website: https://ccss-conference.github.io/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported the "Contagion on Complex Social Systems" workshop on August 14-16, 2023, in Burlington, Vermont. The workshop attracted 50 participants from diverse areas such as epidemiology, network science, forecasting, sociology, and mathematical modeling. The participants included 1 Undergraduate Student, 23 Graduate Students, 8 Postdoctoral Students, 15 Faculty, and 3 Research Scientists. NSF funds were used to support the travel of 28 of these participants. The workshop included 27 talks and three discussion sessions. The workshop topic was the study of "contagion" phenomena in complex social networks. Contagion phenomena include the spread of diseases (such as COVID-19), the spread of information and misinformation on social media, and the spread of opinions in social networks.  Results and ideas in these fields are often compartmentalized in separate disciplines, and approaches are often developed in an ad-hoc manner, making research in the area challenging for investigators who lack a background in other adjacent fields. The conference filled this gap by providing a space where researchers in these disciplines introduced and discussed tools for the analysis of contagion processes in social systems. Another goal of the workshop was to give opportunities to young researchers to interact with senior investigators and present their research, which was achieved by inviting and supporting the travel of over thirty early career researchers from all over the United States.
